stem: The nurse is reviewing the medical records of four infants during a well-child visit. Based on the assessment findings, match each infant's behavior with the expected age range.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
0700: Report initiated for well-child visits.
0715: Infant A, Maria Rodriguez, 6 months old, seen for routine check-up. Mother reports infant smiles spontaneously and rolls from back to front. No known allergies. Feeds on breast milk.
0730: Infant B, David Lee, 12 months old, seen for routine check-up. Mother reports infant is pulling up to stand and says 'mama' and 'dada'. No known allergies. Eats pureed food.
0745: Infant C, Emily Chen, 18 months old, seen for routine check-up. Mother reports infant walks independently and uses a spoon and fork to feed self. No known allergies. Eats table food.
0800: Infant D, Kevin O'Connell, 9 months old, seen for routine check-up. Mother reports infant sits without support and babbles. No known allergies. Eats pureed food.
0815: Infant E, Sarah Johnson, 15 months old, seen for routine check-up. Mother reports infant crawls well and points to objects when asked. No known allergies. Eats mashed food.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Infant A (6 months):
HR: 130 bpm, RR: 30, Temp: 99.0°F (37.2°C), BP: 90/60 mmHg
Infant B (12 months):
HR: 120 bpm, RR: 28, Temp: 98.8°F (37.1°C), BP: 95/65 mmHg
Infant C (18 months):
HR: 110 bpm, RR: 24, Temp: 98.6°F (37.0°C), BP: 100/70 mmHg
Infant D (9 months):
HR: 125 bpm, RR: 29, Temp: 99.2°F (37.3°C), BP: 92/62 mmHg
Infant E (15 months):
HR: 115 bpm, RR: 26, Temp: 98.9°F (37.2°C), BP: 98/68 mmHg

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: All infants show normal lab results within expected ranges for age. Hemoglobin, hematocrit, electrolytes, and white blood cell counts are all within normal limits.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Infant A (6 months):
General: Alert and active. Weight and length appropriate for age. Head control well established. Anterior fontanel open.
Infant B (12 months):
General: Alert and active. Weight and length appropriate for age. Fontanel nearly closed.
Infant C (18 months):
General: Alert and active. Weight and length appropriate for age. Anterior fontanel closed.
Infant D (9 months):
General: Alert and active. Weight and length appropriate for age. Anterior fontanel open.
Infant E (15 months):
General: Alert and active. Weight and length appropriate for age. Anterior fontanel closing.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Standard well-child care plan for all infants, including age-appropriate vaccinations, nutritional guidance, and developmental screening.

rows.text: Pulls up to stand and says 'mama' and 'dada'.
Walks independently and uses a spoon and fork to feed self.
Crawls well and points to objects when asked.

rationale.correct: These behaviors are typical milestones for the assigned age range. Each behavior reflects expected gross motor, fine motor, and language development milestones for the specified age.
rationale.incorrect: Each behavior is not usually associated with the alternative age ranges because infants typically develop skills in a predictable sequence. Selecting an incorrect age would indicate that the infant is either delayed or advanced beyond typical developmental expectations for that period.

answerBreakdown.rationale: Rolling over, typically from back to front, is usually achieved by 6 months. It demonstrates increased muscle strength and coordination.

answerBreakdown.text: Pulling up to stand and saying 'mama' and 'dada'
answerBreakdown.rationale: Pulling up to stand and saying simple words like 'mama' and 'dada' are expected milestones around 12 months, indicating developing gross motor and language skills.

answerBreakdown.text: Walking independently and using a spoon and fork to feed self
answerBreakdown.rationale: Walking independently and using utensils to self-feed are typical of an 18-month-old, demonstrating developed gross and fine motor skills.
Sitting without support and babbling are expected milestones around 9 months.

answerBreakdown.text: Crawls well and points to objects when asked
answerBreakdown.rationale: Crawling well and pointing to objects are typical of a 15-month-old.

clinicalPearls: Developmental milestones are guidelines, and variations can occur. However, significant delays should be investigated.
Monitor for red flags in development, such as lack of eye contact, failure to babble by 12 months, or loss of previously acquired skills.

questionTrap.trap: Students often confuse milestones between closely spaced age ranges (e.g., 9 months vs. 12 months).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the specific fine motor, gross motor, and language skills associated with each age range and use resources such as the Denver Developmental Screening Test to differentiate.

mnemonic.title: SMART Milestones
mnemonic.expansion: Specific milestones for each age, Measurable (can be observed), Attainable (realistic for age), Relevant (directly related to development), Time-bound (within a specific age range).
